s.text: By claiming to serve "working families," Clinton plays it both ways.
This began as a public health crusade, but Clinton has transformed it into an issue of helping parents protect their kids from tobacco pushers.
In the "family" portion of his speech, he bragged about the "Family Medical Leave Act" and called on Congress to "extend family leave to 10 million more Americans."
Democrats used to embrace "working people" while Republicans embraced "family values."
Likewise, in his speech, he avoided the phrase "birth control," which connotes hostility to kids and families.
Equal pay began as a feminist cause, but Clinton has made it a family issue by spotlighting mothers who work outside the home.

In his "family" discussion, he challenged Congress to raise the minimum wage, support HMO regulations, finance studies on arthritis (because "America's families deserve the world's best medical care"), and help public hospitals treat "working families who don't have any insurance."
Republican family issues discriminate between family configurations (straight vs. gay, married vs. unmarried, etc.).
Likewise, in his speech, he avoided the phrase "birth control," which connotes hostility to kids and families.

He urged Congress to "allow people with disabilities to keep health insurance when they go to work" and to "give people between the ages of 55 and 65 who lose their health insurance the chance to buy into Medicare."

He urged Congress to "allow people with disabilities to keep health insurance when they go to work" and to "give people between the ages of 55 and 65 who lose their health insurance the chance to buy into Medicare."
